Hopkins students, never noted for their
activism or confrontational tactics, created
controversy Wednesday night as the Jewish
Students Association and the Progressive
Student Union clashed over the PSU's proPalestinian "teach-in" discussion. Except
for several minor incidents, the program was
peaceful. However, the highly charged tensions and emotions that ipermeated the
event's atmosphere produced the potential
for violence. The problems associated with
the event raised several important questions:
should these controversial speakers have
been invited to speak at Hopkins; should the
JSA have protested in the manner in which
they did; should security have been handled differently, and how should the Student
Council and
Administration
respond to the event?
Originally, some JSA members objected
to the fact that speakers who were affiliated
with the Palestine Liberation Organization
were given the opportunity to speak at
Hopkins. They argued that the PLO is a terrorist organization and inviting them to
speak at Hopkins would be tantamount to
condoning their actions. However, to prohibit advocates of a certain politcial position
from publicly expressing their views is a
violation of their right to free speech, no
matter how repulsive their views might be
to some people. Students, especially, should
be exposed to as many sides of an issue as
possible, so that they can make an enlightened
decision.)t would have been commendable
if the PSU had chosen to present speakers
representing both sides of the issue, however
they were not obligated to do so.
Just as the PSU has the right to invite any
speaker they wish, the JSA has the right to
conduct a peacable protest and to ask critical
questions of the speakers. The candlelight
vigil and the distribution of literature outside Levering Hall prior to the PSU program
was conducted very responsibly. However,
the JSA does not have the right to disrupt
the program, for this is a violation of the
speaker's rights. Sometimes there is a fine
line between protesting and disruption. The
JSA approached this line as they attempted
to enter the L/V room equipped with banners, a flag and a megaphone. PSU members
had to bar the doors so as to prohibit anyone
from entering who had the intention of
heckling or disrupting the program. Some
brief skirmishes erupted in the foyer outside
the L/V room as JSA members came into
contact with people entering the auditorium.
The potential for violent confrontation
would have been severely reduced if the JSA
had limited its demonstration to the area outside the front entrance of Levering Hall
where they had originally assembled. In
retrospect it would have been better if the
JSA had shown more restraint in their protest of the event.
The primary problem of the evening
however was security. In order to constrain
hecklers and disrupters the PSU used a
security force, partially composed of
members of the November 29th Coalition.
The security guards acquired by the PSU
were terrible. They were much too eager to
resort to physical violence to put down minor

disturbances. Physical force was clearly unwarranted in all cases. The blame for the
security problems must be shared by the
PSU, University Security, and the present
procedures for arranging security for campus events.
The onus of providing adequate security
for campus activities falls on the student
group that sponsors the event. Due to lack
of funds, the PSU could not afford to hire
University Security to police the function and
instead relied on members of the November

recur. Wednesday night should stand as a

undergraduate education to
women's concerns.

were given the opportunity to speak at

speak at Hopkins would be tantamount to
condoning their actions. However, to prohibit advocates of a certain politcial position
from publicly expressing their views is a
violation of their right to free speech, no
matter how repulsive their views might be
to some people. Students, especially, should
be exposed to as many sides of an issue as
possible, so that they can make an enlightened
decision.)t would have been commendable
if the PSU had chosen to present speakers
representing both sides of the issue, however
they were not obligated to do so.
Just as the PSU has the right to invite any
speaker they wish, the JSA has the right to
conduct a peacable protest and to ask critical
questions of the speakers. The candlelight
vigil and the distribution of literature outside Levering Hall prior to the PSU program
was conducted very responsibly. However,
the JSA does not have the right to disrupt
the program, for this is a violation of the
speaker's rights. Sometimes there is a fine
line between protesting and disruption. The
JSA approached this line as they attempted
to enter the L/V room equipped with banners, a flag and a megaphone. PSU members
had to bar the doors so as to prohibit anyone
from entering who had the intention of
heckling or disrupting the program. Some
brief skirmishes erupted in the foyer outside
the L/V room as JSA members came into
contact with people entering the auditorium.
The potential for violent confrontation
would have been severely reduced if the JSA
had limited its demonstration to the area outside the front entrance of Levering Hall
where they had originally assembled. In
retrospect it would have been better if the
JSA had shown more restraint in their protest of the event.
The primary problem of the evening
however was security. In order to constrain
hecklers and disrupters the PSU used a
security force, partially composed of
members of the November 29th Coalition.
The security guards acquired by the PSU
were terrible. They were much too eager to
resort to physical violence to put down minor

disturbances. Physical force was clearly unwarranted in all cases. The blame for the
security problems must be shared by the
PSU, University Security, and the present
procedures for arranging security for campus events.
The onus of providing adequate security
for campus activities falls on the student
group that sponsors the event. Due to lack
of funds, the PSU could not afford to hire
University Security to police the function and
instead relied on members of the November
29th Coalition. This was a poor choice on
the PSU's part, yet there is something wrong
with a system that allows an irresponsible
security force to police such a controversial
event. In a case where the sponsoring group
cannot afford to hire a professional security guards, either the Student Council,
through the speakers fund, or the Ad- .
ministration should foot the bill. Although
University Security attended the event, they
chose not to take an active role inside the'
iuditorium until the question and answer
wriod. While it is true that they were not
required to do so, their presence would havel
undoubtedly deterred disruption on both the
part of hecklers and the security force. All
groups involved in the event, therefore, contributed to the uneasy situation.

event sparked, the Student Council recommended that the SAC decharter the Progressive Student Union thereby denying them

disrupting the program. Kaye told the Council that some students were not allowed into the program; no student who attempted

turned away until Hopkins security closed
the doors. The PSU, despite security problems, did the best they could to prevent

they had made a decision before the PSU
program was completed. It was based on
half-truths; some of their information wasincorrect, and they never consulted the PSU.

will be clear that the case to decharter the
PSU is weak. Certainly the PSU made some
errors, but no student group has ever
operated without making some mistakes.

Executive Board have shown themselves to
be rational, deliberative bodies, it is unlikely that either would vote to decharter the

thinking. Everyone made errors in judgment.

totally to blame. Hopefully all involved will
learn from their mistakes and they will not
recur. Wednesday night should stand as a
lesson for the future.

To the Editor:
We would like to respond to
Lisa Rubenstein's letter in the
October 15 News-Letter, in particular her allegation that the
divisions between Hopkins
sororities are based on "black"
and "white."
The difference between
Alpha Phi and Phi Mu and the
other sororities at Hopkins is
that the former two groups are
members of the National
Panhellenic Council. Many
sororities across the country
participate voluntarily in the
NPC, which is concerned with,
among other things, establish
ing equitable rules for rushing
chapter members. NPC groups
such as Alpha Phi and Phi Mu
are "social" sororities;
however, we also emphasize
scholarship and philanthrophy.
Membership in either group
is not determined by color;
also, under Panhellenic rules,
members of non-Panhellenic
groups are welcome to join a
Panhellenic sorority (the only
restriction being that one cannot join more than one
Panhellenic group).
To insinuate that the NPC
sororities at Hopkins are not interested in other Hopkins
women, or other groups of
Hopkins women, because of
color, is totally unjustified.
Sincerely,
Peggy Fogelman, President
Barbara Busharis, Vice Pres.

Torremolinos Tacky Yet Tasty
BY DOREEN MORAN
Fine dining is not impossible in
Baltimore. The city's unique ethnic
diversity practically guarantees a
delicious experience in at least one of
the numerous restaurants under each
ethnic catagory. If Spanish cuisine is
your preference, then Torremolinos
is just the place for you.
The decor is a bit tacky. You'll
find yourself staring at walls of
tapestried bulls and collector plates
of Don Quixote. But the dim, romantically candlelit Torremolinos
transcends this first impression and
delivers maximum atmosphere, maximum relaxation, at a moderate price.
The first thing you'll want to do is
order a pitcher of sangria. At $8.50
for the pitcher, this mellow, yet
potent concoction is tar cheaper this
way than at $1.75 per glass. It's also
nice to be able to down a glass within
a few minutes and pour yourself
another without having to worry .if
the waiter is going to think you're a
lush. Chunky, with ice and pieces of
fresh fruit, this sangria is the perfect
complement to your dinner.

Torremolino's menu is large and
selections are printed in both Spanish
and English. There are a number of
appetizers, soups and salads to
choose from. We tried the shrimp in
garlic sauce and snails in the same.
Ten plump shrimp were served hot in
a miniature cast-iron skillet, swimming in a zesty, yet not overpowering
cream sauce. The snails,* six large
specimens, had less sauce and, my
companion complained, not enough
garlic. However, they were plump
and tender and well worth the $4.00.
The shrimp were a steal at $3.75. Try
something similar at the Belvedere's
Owl Bar and you'll find yourself—
maybe— with five tiny shrimp and
lots of garnish for a steep $5.75.
With such a varied menu, including chicken, beef, veal, and
seafood, it's difficult to choose an entree. However, the Paella Marinara
proved an excellent choice, the rice
flavorful and chock full of chunks of
clam, shrimp and an undetermined
but tasty white fish. The paella, rolled over to our table on a cart and
served from a large chafing dish by
our waiter, came surrounded by halv-

ed Maine lobster, and numerous baked mussels and clams. Not only was
it excellently prepared, but artfully
served and enormously contenting.
The huge portion, $22.75 for two,
was enough for us to consider skipping dessert. However, we had had a
glimpse of the dessert cart and the
temptation was too strong to resist.
Desserts are not plentiful—there
were only four choices the Saturday
night we were there—but those four
looked luscious, at $2.00 each. We
both went for the chocolate mousse,
a large serving of a light, yet filling
cream, topped with shaved chocolate.
We both agreed that this was one of
